habitat: Well-drained floodplain forests, riverbanks, rich mesic forests, sand and gravel-bar woodlands, old alluvial fields, and successional forests on disturbed uplands (especially near rivers and streams).
Mesic to dry, calcareous upland forests and woodlands; rich floodplain forests, locally common in areas underlain by limestone, dolomite, or calcareous shales
Disturbed forests, old fields, fencerows, road banks, and urban woodlots; especially abundant in base-rich soils. Common throughout, and highly invasive in both ruderal and natural habitats.

Well-drained floodplain forests, mesic to dry-mesic upland forests, and various disturbed, open to shaded habitats; most prevalent in nutrient-rich soils. Common in the mountains and Piedmont; infrequent in the Coastal Plain
Disturbed forests, old fields, fencerows, road banks, and urban woodlots;
Well-drained, base-rich nutrient-poor soils
Mesic to dry forests and old fields.
Mesic to dry forests and old fields.
Mesic to dry upland forests, but most numerous in moderately to strongly base-rich soils
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to rather dry upland forests and woodlands, well-drained floodplain forests, and high-elevation deciduous forests
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry upland forests and woodlands; tolerant of a range of soil chemistries, occurring widely on base-rich to extremely infertile substrates
Floodplains, mesic to dry upland; nutrient rich
Dry to mesic upland forest, calcareous soils
Mesic and dry-mesic upland forests, boulder field forests, seepage swamp hummocks, clearings and borders
Weedy clearings, old fields, pastures, lawns, and cultivated soils. Common in the Coastal Plain, Piedmont, and nw. mountains; infrequent in the wc. and sw. mountains.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry-mesic upland forests, very well-drained floodplain terraces, and bluffs; most common on well-drained, acidic, nutrient-poor soils
Mesic to dry mesic upland forest, base-rich soils, well-drained

Mesic to damp roadsides and other open, disturbed habitats. Frequent in the mountains; infrequent to rare in the Piedmont, although now apparently spreading rapidly in the northern half of the province; very rare in the Coastal Plain (York Co.).
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry mesic upland forest
Mesic and dry-mesic upland forests, well-drained floodplain forests, seepage swamps, alluvial swamps, and tidal swamps; on uplands, it is most abundant in base-rich soils
Mesic to dry mesic upland forest
Nearly ubiquitous in wet to dry forests, old fields, disturbed floodplains, and various open habitats; shade-tolerant and very invasive in many natural community types. Common throughout.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora;NYCgovparks.org

habitat: Floodplain forests, swamp hummocks, mesic to dry-mesic upland forests, wet flatwoods, shaded clearings, and other moist, often shaded, disturbed habitats. Now common in most parts of the state.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry upland forests, rocky woodlands, seepage swamps, floodplain forests and swamps, wet flatwoods, and depression pons

Mesic upland forests (both disturbed and undisturbed), well-drained stream bottoms, and shaded clearings. Recently discovered at multiple sites in the Northern Blue Ridge, northern Piedmont, northern Ridge and Valley, and central Piedmont regions; locally abundant, covering many acres at some sites. There is an unvouchered sight record from Prince William County.

Roadsides, clearings, disturbed forests, disturbed outcrops, alluvial fields, flood-scoured bars and shores; increasingly appearing in forested settings, especially following disturbances such as logging or windthrows. Currently frequent to locally common in the northernmost Piedmont counties; scattered elsewhere in the northern half of the state, but highly invasive and evidently increasing its range.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry upland forests and woodlands, and montane alluvial forests
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic and dry-mesic (occasionally dry) upland forests, old fields
Wet to dry forests and woodlands throughout
Dry to mesic upland forest
Mesic to dry mesic upland forest, well drained bottomlands
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora
Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry mesic upland forest, mid to high elev.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry secondary forests, old fields, fencerows
Wetland and upland forests, clearings, old fields
Mesic to dry upland forests, well drained alluvial forests, rocky woodlands, barrens, clearings, old fields, and roadsides. Common throughout, except in far se. Virginia.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora; NYCgovparks.org

habitat: Mesic to dry forests, woodlands, barrens, clearings, old fields, pastures, and road banks
Mesic to dry-mesic (rarely dry) upland forests, clearings, old fields, and roadsides; especially abundant in base-rich soils.
Dry to mesic forests and woodlands, old fields, fencerows
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: In a wide range of upland and wetland habitats. Common throughout.
Fields, pastures, roadsides, and waste ground; a pernicious weed in cultivated fields. Common throughout
Fields, gardens, and other open, disturbed habitats; also a common invader of floodplain forests and rich, mesic forests. Common throughout.

Mesic to dry forests (where often shade-stressed), woodlands, well-drained floodplains, pastures, and old fields, especially, but by no means exclusively, in base-rich substrates. Common throughout. This shrub is now invasive in dry rocky woodlands and barrens on metabasalt and diabase in northern Virginia where it was absent 20 years ago

Ubiquitous in a wide range of habitats, including mesic to dry upland forests, floodplain forests, swamps, boulderfields, rock outcrops, old fields, clearings, and fencerows; typically in more mesic and fertile sites than T. pubescens. Common throughout the state.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to dry mesic upland forest, rocky, disturbed habitats
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Ubiquitous n a notably wide range of forested to open, wet to dry habitats and vegetation types. Common throughout.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Open, wet to dry habitats.
references: Digital Atlas of the Virginia Flora

habitat: Mesic to damp roadsides and other open, disturbed habitats. Frequent in the mountains; infrequent to rare in the Piedmont, although now apparently spreading rapidly in the northern half of the province; very rare in the Coastal Plain (York Co.).
